author: By Gia Kourlas
title: FKA twigs Dances Martha Graham: ‘This Is Art in Its Truest Form’
description: Once a young bunhead, the acclaimed musical artist is taking the stage with the Martha Graham Dance Company. For her, it’s holy grail territory.
content: The rebellious spirit of Martha Graham has found a rebellious soul mate in another creative powerhouse. A classically trained dancer, she’s known in the world as an acclaimed recording artist. She moves like water. Her pole dancing is pretty astounding, too. This is FKA twigs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 310
description: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura May Todd
title: In Milan, a Party With T-Shaped Ice Cubes, Balloons and Pasta
description: To toast the Salone del Mobile and the 20th anniversary of T Magazine, the designer Ramdane Touhami transformed the Villa Necchi Campiglio into an ode to the letter T.
content: On Monday evening, T Magazine held its annual party to help kick off the Salone del Mobile design fair in Milan. For the sixth year, guests flocked to Villa Necchi Campiglio, the 1935 Rationalist-style home designed by the Italian architect Piero Portaluppi. But this year, the cause for celebration was twofold: The event also marked the magazine’s 20th anniversary, and to honor the occasion, T’s editor in chief, Hanya Yanagihara, commissioned the Parisian multidisciplinary artist Ramdane Touhami to oversee the party’s design.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Whitey Herzog, Hall of Fame Cardinals Manager, Dies at 92
description: He won three pennants and a World Series as the St. Louis skipper, promoting what was called “Whiteyball,” combining speed, defense and pitching.
content: Whitey Herzog, the Hall of Fame manager who led the St. Louis Cardinals to three pennants and a World Series championship in the 1980s, died on Monday in St. Louis. He was 92 and had been the second-oldest Hall of Famer after Willie Mays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Melania Trump Avoids the Courtroom, but Is Said to Share Her Husband’s Anger
description: Melania Trump has long referred to the hush-money case involving Stormy Daniels as her husband’s problem, not hers. But she has privately called the trial a “disgrace” that could threaten his campaign.
content: In January 2018, when she first saw reports that her husband had paid off a porn star, Melania Trump was furious. She jetted off to Palm Beach, leaving the president to languish in Washington. She eventually returned, only to take a separate car to Donald J. Trump’s first State of the Union address.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Mozur and David E. Sanger
title: Microsoft Makes High-Stakes Play in Tech Cold War With Emirati A.I. Deal
description: Microsoft said it would invest $1.5 billion in G42, an Emirati company with ties to China, as Washington and Beijing maneuver to secure tech influence in the Persian Gulf.
content: Microsoft said on Tuesday that it would make a $1.5 billion investment in G42, an artificial intelligence giant in the United Arab Emirates, in a deal largely orchestrated by the Biden administration to box out China as Washington and Beijing battle over who will exercise technological influence in the Persian Gulf region and beyond.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Appears Skeptical of Using Obstruction Law to Charge Jan. 6 Rioters
description: The justices considered the gravity of the assault and whether prosecutors have been stretching the law to reach members of the mob responsible for the attack.
content: The Supreme Court seemed wary on Tuesday of letting prosecutors use a federal obstruction law to charge hundreds of rioters involved in the Capitol attack on Jan. 6, 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Johnson’s Plan for Ukraine Aid Meets Republican Pushback, Muddying Its Path
description: The Republican speaker’s strategy for moving foreign aid measures for Israel and Ukraine through the House has outraged many in his own party, increasing calls for his ouster.
content: Speaker Mike Johnson on Tuesday encountered stiff resistance from Republicans as he embarked on a complicated and politically perilous strategy to push legislation through the House to send aid to Israel and Ukraine — all while beating back a threat to his own job.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: U.S. Lays Out Protections for Assange if He Is Extradited
description: American officials sought to reassure the U.K. about Julian Assange’s treatment should the former WikiLeaks founder, who has been indicted by the U.S., be sent there.
content: The possibility that Julian Assange, the WikiLeaks founder, could be extradited to the United States seemed to edge closer on Tuesday, after American officials sent assurances to British authorities that he would not face the death penalty or be persecuted for his nationality, and that he could seek First Amendment protections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley and Kate Christobek
title: Day 2 of Trump’s Criminal Trial: Five Takeaways
description: Lawyers chose seven jurors to help decide the case against the former president, who is accused of falsifying business records to cover up a sexual scandal involving a porn star.
content: After the first day of jury selection in Donald J. Trump’s criminal trial saw the dismissal of dozens of potential jurors who said they could not be impartial, the first seven jurors were chosen on Tuesday as the defendant looked on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: 4 in ‘God’s Misfits’ Group Charged in Disappearance of 2 Kansas Women
description: The four arrested on murder and kidnapping charges were from Oklahoma and, according to a relative, were members of an anti-government group by that name, the authorities said.
content: Four people involved in an anti-government group they called God’s Misfits have been arrested on murder and kidnapping charges in the disappearance of two Kansas women who last month were likely targeted over a custody dispute, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher and Alexandra Stevenson
title: China’s Economy, Propelled by Its Factories, Grew More Than Expected
description: China’s big bet on manufacturing helped to counteract its housing slowdown in the first three months of the year, but other countries are worried about a flood of Chinese goods.
content: The Chinese economy grew more than expected in the first three months of the year, new data shows, as China built more factories and exported huge amounts of goods to counter a severe real estate crisis and sluggish spending at home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Why Germany Can’t Break Up With China
description: China remains one of the most important markets for Germany’s export-driven economy, prompting a three-day visit by the German chancellor, who has stressed the importance of open markets.
content: When Germany’s chancellor, Olaf Scholz, took office in 2021, he pledged that his government would shift his country’s relationship with China away from one of economic dependence. Three years later, talk of scaling back reliance on China has been replaced with calls for equal access to China’s market for foreign firms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esther Zuckerman
title: How They Pulled Off the Ending to ‘Civil War’
description: The action thriller from Alex Garland concludes with an explosive sequence in the nation’s capital. A behind-the-scenes look at how it was done.
content: This article contains spoilers for the film “Civil War.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: U.S. Plans New Sanctions on Iran After Attack on Israel, Officials Say
description: The U.S. treasury secretary, Janet Yellen, said that sanctions could be announced “in the coming days” and would likely focus on oil exports and imports of military hardware.
content: The United States plans to impose new sanctions on Iran in the coming days to punish it for the attacks on Israel over the weekend, U.S. officials said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Hoberman
title: ‘Man’s Castle’: Free Love, Hard Times
description: Restored to its original length and screening at the Museum of Modern Art, this 1933 movie starring Spencer Tracy feels at once surprisingly frank and disquietingly coy.
content: A celebrant of redemptive love, Frank Borzage (1893-1962) was the most romantic of classic Hollywood directors and, however unconventionally, perhaps the most religious as well. “Man’s Castle” (1933) conflates an economic crisis — namely the Great Depression — with a spiritual one. The movie also represents premarital pregnancy as salvation rather than sin, and scenes were consequently cut for its post-Production Code rerelease in the late 1930s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joan Nathan
title: At Passover, the Only Constant Is Changing Recipes
description: Joan Nathan, a doyenne of Jewish American cuisine, has long treasured the holiday and witnessed its evolution through food.
content: In 1980, my husband Allan and I hosted our first Passover Seder at our home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By R. Jisung Park
title: We Don’t See What Climate Change Is Doing to Us
description: We need to grapple with the many hidden and little-understood but highly damaging effects of climate change.
content: Many of us realize climate change is a threat to our well-being. But what we have not yet grasped is that the devastation wreaked by climate change comes not just from headline-grabbing catastrophes but also from the subtler accumulation of innumerable slow and unequal burns that are already underway — the nearly invisible costs that may not raise the same alarm but that, in their pervasiveness and inequality, may be much more harmful than commonly realized. Recognizing these hidden costs will be essential as we prepare ourselves for the warming that we have ahead of us.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: I.M.F. Sees Steady Growth but Warns of Rising Protectionism
description: The International Monetary Fund offered an upbeat economic outlook but said that new trade barriers and escalating wars could worsen inflation.
content: The global economy is approaching a soft landing after several years of geopolitical and economic turmoil, the International Monetary Fund said on Tuesday. But it warned that risks remain, including stubborn inflation, the threat of escalating global conflicts and rising protectionism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: thoroughfare
description: This word has appeared in 104 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word thoroughfare has appeared in 104 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on April 2 in “Rome’s Future Is a Walk Through Its Past” by Elisabetta Povoledo:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Deal’s Demise Gave Tehran Opportunity
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, April 16, 2024.
content: “The shadow war is now breaking into the open, and without some rules, they are on an escalatory path.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor and Maya Tekeli
title: Copenhagen’s Old Stock Exchange Building Partly Collapses in Fire
description: The 17th-century building, one of the city’s best-known structures, was once the financial center of Denmark.
content: The old stock exchange building in downtown Copenhagen — one of the city’s oldest structures, known for its elaborate spire of intertwined dragon tails — partly collapsed in a large fire early Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cassandra Vinograd, Isabel Kershner and Michael Levenson
title: Israel Weighs Response to Iran’s Attack as Allies Push for Restraint
description: The Israeli war cabinet met again on Monday to discuss the strike, with some hawkish members of the prime minister’s government calling for a swift and forceful retaliation.
content: Israel’s war cabinet on Monday met to weigh possible responses to Iran’s missile and drone attack over the weekend, as the United States, Britain and other allies strongly urged Israel to show restraint and sought to de-escalate tensions between the two regional powers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Hamby
title: U.S. Limits Deadly Mining Dust as Black Lung Resurges
description: Federal regulation capping toxic airborne silica has been decades in the making. The delay has cost miners dearly.
content: Federal regulators on Tuesday issued new protections for miners against a type of dust long known to cause deadly lung ailments — changes recommended by government researchers a half-century ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Swan, Maggie Haberman and Michael Crowley
title: Trump Holds Series of Meetings With Foreign Leaders
description: The former president has had several private interactions with foreign heads of state and their emissaries. He plans to meet Wednesday with Poland’s president.
content: Donald J. Trump plans to meet with the right-wing president of Poland this week, the latest in a series of his private interactions with leaders or emissaries from countries from the Persian Gulf to Eastern Europe, many of whom share an affinity with his brand of politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: Smartmatic and OAN Settle Defamation Suit
description: Smartmatic, an elections technology company, had accused the conservative broadcaster of amplifying baseless claims about election fraud.
content: The voting technology company Smartmatic reached a settlement on Tuesday in its defamation lawsuit against One America News Network, a far-right broadcaster, over the amplification of election falsehoods about the 2020 presidential election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich
title: These Are the 42 Questions Prospective Trump Jurors Are Being Asked
description: Once they are chosen, jurors will be asked to decide whether Donald J. Trump falsified business records to cover up a sex scandal. But first they must answer these questions.
content: Jury selection is often a lengthy process, but in the first criminal trial of a former American president, currently taking place in a Manhattan criminal courthouse, it’s going more slowly than normal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa
title: A Wealthy Democratic Representative Is Among Top Self-Funders in Senate Primary History
description: Representative David Trone of Maryland was spending millions from his personal fortune even before his recent use of a racial slur drew criticism.
content: Representative David Trone, a Democrat who apologized for using a racial slur during a recent House committee meeting, has poured nearly $42 million from his personal fortune into his Senate bid in Maryland, according to the latest federal quarter filings, putting him among the top self-funders in Senate primary history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wilson and Chelsia Rose Marcius
title: A Quiet Sunday Night in Syracuse, and Then a Deadly Ambush
description: A routine traffic stop led to the deaths of a police officer and a sheriff’s deputy in a shooting outside a suburban home. The gunman was also killed.
content: The deadliest day in Syracuse police history in over 30 years began when two officers attempted to pull over a gray Honda Civic on a quiet corner outside a church. The car peeled away, out of sight — but not before the police officers clocked its license plate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Interior Said to Reject Industrial Road Through Alaskan Wilderness
description: A mining company wants to build a 211-mile industrial road through Alaskan wilderness to reach a large copper deposit. The Interior Department says it would harm wildlife and communities.
content: The Biden administration is expected to deny permission for a 211-mile industrial road through fragile Alaskan wilderness to a large copper deposit, handing a victory to environmentalists in an election year when the president wants to underscore his credentials as a climate leader and conservationist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: The Smothering of Abortion Rights Reveals Something Else About Republicans
description: Both the federal and the Arizona Supreme Courts have conjured a past that rejects the right to bodily autonomy.
content: Last Monday, Donald Trump said that abortion rights were best left to the states. “The states,” he said, “will determine by vote or legislation or perhaps both, and whatever they decide must be the law of the land. In this case, the law of the state.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: A Diplomatic Victory of Uncertain Staying Power
description: President Biden successfully assembled a coalition to defend Israel against Iran’s aerial attack, but the cycle of retaliation could continue, challenging the White House’s efforts to avert a sustained conflict.
content: It was so close. Had just one missile or drone gotten through and killed a lot of Israelis, American officials feared, the region could have gone up in flames.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Justices Questioned a Law Used to Charge Jan. 6 Rioters
description: Also, the U.S. is planning new sanctions on Iran. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
content: The Supreme Court appeared wary during a hearing today of allowing prosecutors to use a federal obstruction law to charge hundreds of rioters involved in the Capitol attack on Jan. 6, 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Walker and Niraj Chokshi
title: Boeing Defends Safety of 787 Dreamliner After Whistle-Blower’s Claims
description: After a Boeing engineer went public with safety concerns, the company invited reporters to its South Carolina factory and top engineers vouched for the plane.
content: Boeing sought on Monday to reassure the public of the safety of its 787 Dreamliner plane days before a whistle-blower is scheduled to testify before Congress about his concerns regarding the jet’s structural integrity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Loudin
title: How to Turn a Bike Ride Into a Bike Workout
description: Cycling isn’t just fun. It can also deliver big fitness gains with the right gear and strategy.
content: There’s no better way to take in a perfect spring day than from a bike. The songbirds are back, the daffodils are blooming and your dusty 10-speed is looking for a rider.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Audit Questions Purchase of $19,000 Lectern by Arkansas Governor’s Office
description: The legislative audit found several ways that the heavily scrutinized purchase potentially violated state law. Gov. Sarah Huckabee Sanders criticized the findings.
content: Legislative auditors in Arkansas found that the purchase last year of a $19,000 lectern by Gov. Sarah Huckabee Sanders’s office potentially violated state laws, according to a report released on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: ‘Canceled’ for Protesting Cancel Culture, Europe’s Right-Wingers Rejoice
description: A mayor in Brussels gave no explanation of why he thought it necessary to try to stop a conservative gathering from taking place, other than saying he wanted to “guarantee public safety.”
content: A mayor in Brussels on Tuesday sent police officers to break up a gathering of prominent, self-described “anti-woke” conservatives from across Europe, including Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary, declaring “the far right is not welcome” before the authorities quickly retreated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Sexton
title: Farewell, and Thanks, to a Man Who Kept Kids Safe
description: When they lost their beloved crossing guard, the students at Avenues The World School — Spider-Man, Wilder, Miss Seattle and the rest — paid tribute in cocoa and chalk.
content: From the corner of West 25th Street in Manhattan, it takes 34 steps to cross 10th Avenue, more if it is a kindergartner dawdling, sippy cup in hand, to the private school on the other side. To get to Avenues The World School by crossing West 25th Street takes only 16 steps, even fewer if it is a frantic 12th grader bounding to be on time for first period.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Horvath, Adam Westbrook and Lindsay Crouse
title: Criminalizing Homelessness Won’t Make It Go Away
description: Hundreds of thousands of people are homeless. This filmmaker wants you to see them.
content: If you live in one of America’s cities, you probably see homeless people all the time. You might pass them on your way to work. Maybe you avoid eye contact. If they ask you for money, maybe you pretend you didn’t hear, and walk on by.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Ken Holtzman, Who Pitched Two No-Hitters for the Cubs, Is Dead at 78
description: He was part of the Oakland A’s dynasty in the ’70s. He was also the winningest Jewish pitcher in Major League Baseball, surpassing Sandy Koufax.
content: Ken Holtzman, a left-hander who pitched two no-hitters for the Chicago Cubs and won three World Series with the Oakland A’s in a 15-season career, died on Monday in St. Louis. He was 78.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas
title: In Pennsylvania, Biden slams Trump as he calls for a fairer tax code.
description: In Scranton, his hometown, the president discussed tax policy in terms of economic fairness, arguing that Donald Trump’s tax cuts benefited billionaires.
content: President Biden kicked off a three-day tour of Pennsylvania, a crucial battleground state, with a speech on Tuesday that focused on taxes and aimed to contrast his policies with those of former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By S. Kirk Walsh
title: A Tale of Four Troubled and Talented Sisters, Told With Irish Flair
description: There’s more than blarney in Caoilinn Hughes’s riotous, ambitiously structured new novel.
content: Caoilinn Hughes’s exuberant third novel opens with Olwen Flattery, a geology professor, lecturing her undergraduate students about tectonic convergence. “Just imagine the force it would take to move a mountain! And we’re not talking about violent, sudden processes, like an earthquake shouldering up a mountain range. No. These forces are so incremental and immense, so imperceivable and unstoppable, that there’s no halting their progress.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Why Is California Called California?
description: Probably because of a griffin-riding warrior queen.
content: A 16th-century Spanish romance novel tells of an earthly paradise “on the right hand of the Indies,” with steep cliffs and rocky shores. On this island utopia, which like Atlantis and El Dorado is full of riches, “there was no metal but gold” and the rulers were all strong Black women.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wadzanai Mhute
title: When a Family’s Dysfunction Mirrors a Nation’s
description: “Crooked Seeds,” by Karen Jennings, is set in a drought-stricken South Africa where its fraught history is ever-present.
content: When Nelson Mandela was released from Victor Verster Prison in 1990, after 27 years of incarceration, there was hope in the air. He and his wife, Winnie, raised clenched fists in triumph as they emerged from the prison gates, surrounded by supporters of different races. His release heralded a South Africa on the verge of transformation. The promise of a new rainbow nation drove masses in 1994 to the first inclusive general elections, but 30 years on, South Africa is floundering with power cuts, a tanking economy and xenophobia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Savors Day One of the Trump Trial
description: After the ex-president seemed to fall asleep in court, Jimmy Kimmel said it was “nice to see even Donald Trump is exhausted by Donald Trump.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esau McCaulley
title: One Thing Parents Can Control
description: As parents, we cannot shield our sons and daughters from the world’s cruelty or our failures, but we can try to counter those things.
content: My father was a long-haul truck driver. He piloted one of those eighteen-wheelers that had a horn that could raise the dead. As a kid I longed to join him on his journeys and discover something of the world beyond Huntsville, Ala., where we lived.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: How Washington Played A.I. Matchmaker
description: The White House laid the ground work for Microsoft’s $1.5 billion investment in an Emirati artificial intelligence start-up, a deal meant to box out Beijing.
content: A relatively small deal — by Microsoft’s standards, anyway — is leading to big geopolitical ripples on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Otterman
title: Columbia President Is Next to Be Grilled About Antisemitism by Congress
description: Columbia University’s president, Nemat Shafik, will speak to the same congressional committee before which the Harvard and University of Pennsylvania presidents stumbled.
content: Four months after an explosive congressional hearing on antisemitism precipitated the resignations of two Ivy League presidents, another university president is about to step to the hot seat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: One Under a Birdie
description: Adam Vincent keeps us young at heart.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland
title: 5 Takeaways From a Year of Medicaid Upheaval
description: In the year after a pandemic-era policy preserving Medicaid coverage lapsed, more than 20 million people were dropped from the program at some point.
content: Lindsey McNeil and her 7-year-old daughter, Noelle, who has cerebral palsy and epilepsy, were jolted by an alert they received from Florida’s Department of Children and Families late last month that Noelle would be losing her Medicaid coverage 10 days later.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Christobek
title: Here’s a Recap of Day 1 of Trump’s Criminal Trial
description: The defense cited several issues as it pushed for Juan M. Merchan, the judge, to be removed from the case. The attempt failed, and hours later, jury selection began.
content: The criminal trial of Donald J. Trump, the nation’s 45th president and the Republican Party’s presumptive nominee, started Monday with potential jurors assembling in a drab New York City courtroom as Mr. Trump looked on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Cumming-Bruce
title: U.N. Panel Says Israel Is Obstructing Its Investigation of the Oct. 7 Attack
description: The commission, which is looking at possible human rights violations by Hamas and Israel, said it had still amassed large amounts of evidence. Israel has accused the commission of bias.
content: Members of a United Nations commission said on Tuesday that Israel was obstructing their efforts to investigate possible human rights violations on Oct. 7 and in the ensuing war between Israel and Hamas. But they said the commission had still shared large amounts of evidence with the International Criminal Court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser and Tracey Tully
title: Senator Menendez, Charged in Bribery Scheme, May Blame His Wife
description: According to newly unsealed documents, Senator Robert Menendez may testify that Nadine Menendez hid information from him, leading him to believe that “nothing unlawful was taking place.”
content: Senator Robert Menendez may blame his wife, Nadine Menendez, for the bribery charges the couple is facing by claiming that she hid information from him and led him to believe that “nothing unlawful was taking place,” according to court papers unsealed on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: California Man Gets 9 Years in Firebombing of Planned Parenthood Clinic
description: The clinic, which provided abortion, birth control and other health services in Costa Mesa, Calif., was the target of a “brazen attack” in 2022, a prosecutor said.
content: A California man who used a Molotov cocktail to firebomb a clinic providing abortion services was sentenced to nine years in prison on Monday in the 2022 attack on the facility, which is operated by the Planned Parenthood Federation of America in Costa Mesa, Calif., federal authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By DAVID GELLES
title: Has Tesla Peaked?
description: And what would that mean for the climate?
content: Tesla is in a bad spot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Cade Metz, Stella Tan, Michael Simon Johnson, Mooj Zadie, Rikki Novetsky, Marc Georges, Liz O. Baylen, Diane Wong, Dan Powell, Pat McCusker and Chris Wood
title: A.I.’s Original Sin
description: A Times investigation found that tech giants altered their own rules to train their newest artificial intelligence systems.
content: A Times investigation shows how the country’s biggest technology companies, as they raced to build powerful new artificial intelligence systems, bent and broke the rules from the start.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Colter Walls
title: A Pulitzer-Winning Composer Puts His Operatic Spin on Edith Wharton
description: Anthony Davis has written operas based on recent history. But now he is adapting, and dramatically changing, Wharton’s 1912 novel “The Reef.”
content: The composer and pianist Anthony Davis is known for drawing inspiration from real-world figures in his operas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson and Melissa Eddy
title: Germany’s Leader Walks a Fine Line in China
description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz tried to promote German business interests while delivering warnings from Europe about trade and geopolitical tensions.
content: Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany tried to strike a delicate balance on a trip to China this week, promoting business ties with his country’s biggest trading partner while raising concerns over its surge of exports to Europe and its support for Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul
title: U.S.C. Cancels Valedictorian’s Speech After Pro-Israel Groups Object
description: The university cited security concerns at the graduation. But the student, who is Muslim, said the school was “succumbing to a campaign of hate meant to silence my voice.”
content: The University of Southern California said it has canceled plans for a graduation speech by this year’s valedictorian, Asna Tabassum, who is Muslim. The school said the decision stemmed from security concerns based on emails and other electronic communications warning of a plan to disrupt the commencement, including at least one that targeted Ms. Tabassum.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: High Winds Scuttle Burning of Snowman in Zurich, Disappointing the Swiss
description: The burning of the effigy known as the Böögg is the finale of Sechseläuten, an annual spring festival akin to Groundhog Day. The normally stoic Swiss wallowed in disappointment.
content: Imagine if Punxsutawney Phil just didn’t show up one year. How would people know how much longer winter would last?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Caitlin Clark and the Best-Dressed at the W.N.B.A. Draft
description: The next class of basketball stars are ready for their close-ups. Finally, fashion is paying attention.
content: When it comes to peacocks, it’s hard to beat male athletes. Their tunnel walks have been painstakingly documented; their fits have dominated the draft day conversations for the N.B.A. and the N.F.L.; their love of Vuitton and Hermès has been parlayed into brands of their own.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: The Paris Olympics’ One Sure Thing: Cyberattacks
description: “We will be attacked,” the official responsible for fending off cyberthreats said. To prepare, organizers have been hosting war games and paying “bug bounties” to hackers.
content: In his office on one of the upper floors of the headquarters of the Paris Olympic organizing committee, Franz Regul has no doubt what is coming.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: La Scala Opera Taps an Italian to Be Its Next Leader
description: Fortunato Ortombina, the general director of Teatro La Fenice, Venice’s opera house, will succeed Dominique Meyer, a respected French impresario.
content: The Teatro alla Scala in Milan, one of the world’s most prestigious and storied opera houses, announced Tuesday that its next leader would be Fortunato Ortombina, who is currently general director of Venice’s opera house, Teatro La Fenice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: 6 New Songs You Should Hear Now
description: Hear tracks from Tyla, Chappell Roan, Young Miko and more.
content: As someone who doesn’t love music festivals and has an outsize distaste for wind, it seems very unlikely that I will ever attend Coachella. If my teenage heroes No Doubt reuniting — and bringing out the pop star I most wish existed when I was a teenager, Olivia Rodrigo — did not convince me to make the pilgrimage to Indio, Calif., then it feels safe to say nothing can.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana G. Smith
title: We Have Tick Medications for Dogs. Why Not for People?
description: Certain concerns have hindered development, but several Lyme prevention drugs are currently being tested in humans.
content: Q: Every three months, I give my dog a beef-flavored chew that kills any ticks that bite her. She has also been vaccinated against Lyme disease. Why don’t these options exist for people?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Participant, Maker of Films With Social Conscience, Calls It Quits
description: The company had critical and commercial hits over two decades but never made money consistently and faced a challenging entertainment landscape.
content: For 20 years, Participant Media has been Hollywood’s pre-eminent maker of activist entertainment, backing socially conscious films like “An Inconvenient Truth,” a climate change cri de coeur, and “Wonder,” about a boy with birth defects. Its movies have won 21 Academy Awards.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: An Upper West Side Home With Wallpaper Murals and Terrazzo Everywhere
description: “We were pushing it,” the architect said of the design, which includes a hidden playroom and a soaking tub where you wouldn’t expect it.
content: When Sandra Davis and Bruce Johnson bought a garden-level duplex in a 1910 townhouse on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, they knew they’d have to accept its quirks, at least for a while.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays
title: Protesters Disrupt Mayor Adams’s Speech to Business Leaders
description: The mayor’s speech at a “power breakfast” was interrupted by demonstrators who stormed the stage and accused him of abandoning the working class.
content: A handful of protesters disrupted a speech by Mayor Eric Adams on Tuesday, storming a stage and accusing the mayor of caring more about the needs of the real estate lobby than the working-class New Yorkers he often talks about.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein
title: Lawmakers Question Bank of America About Leon Black’s Payments to Epstein
description: A Senate committee sent a letter asking the bank whether it had adequately followed procedures before clearing $158 million in payments.
content: A U.S. Senate committee investigating the tax avoidance work that Jeffrey Epstein, the registered sex offender, did for the private equity mogul Leon Black has questioned Bank of America over Mr. Black’s hefty payments to Mr. Epstein, according to a letter viewed by The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: Under Pressure From Trump, Arizona Republicans Weigh Response to 1864 Abortion Ban
description: Liberal activists are proposing a ballot measure that would enshrine the right to an abortion in the state Constitution. Republicans in the State Legislature are considering plans to undermine it.
content: Facing mounting pressure to strike down a near-total abortion ban revived last week by Arizona’s Supreme Court, Republican state legislators are considering efforts to undermine a planned ballot measure this fall that would enshrine abortion rights in the Arizona Constitution, according to a presentation obtained by The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynn Steger Strong
title: Parenting in a Pandemic, and Other Tales of Woe
description: Gillian Linden’s slim debut novel, “Negative Space,” explores the being and nothingness of modern motherhood.
content: Reading Gillian Linden’s “Negative Space,” I kept thinking of the Lydia Davis story “Fear.” The story opens with a woman running out of her house, “face white and overcoat flapping wildly.” “Emergency, emergency,” the woman says. In the next sentence, Davis tells us that “nothing has really happened” to this woman, but still the community comes out to comfort her. “Fear,” like Linden’s novel, grapples with an amorphous sense of something coming, threatening; it situates the reader inside a world in which awful things exist but nothing, really, has happened yet. In the meantime, the world around both the woman in Davis’s story and the one in Linden’s novel mostly wants her to be quiet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madison Malone Kircher
title: ‘We Are So Back’ Is So Back
description: The phrase has become ubiquitous online as a way to celebrate life’s small pleasures — at least until “it’s so over.”
content: Before Lana Del Rey took the stage at Coachella last weekend, she rode through the crowd on the back of a motorcycle in a sparkly blue dress with her long blond hair flowing in the wind. It was her first performance at the event in a decade, and for some it recalled the bygone era of 2014 — perhaps a simpler time, when the festival was in what many consider its golden age.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dodai Stewart
title: What No One Seems to Know About Honking in New York
description: Honking takes its toll on New Yorkers, and it doesn’t have to be this way.
content: Good morning. It’s Tuesday, and we’ll look at the dangers of tooting your own horn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: Ukraine’s Big Vulnerabilities: Ammunition, Soldiers and Air Defense
description: The shortages add up to a dire situation for Ukraine in the third year of the war, presenting commanders with near impossible choices on how to deploy limited resources.
content: Ukraine’s top military commander has issued a bleak assessment of the army’s positions on the eastern front, saying they have “worsened significantly in recent days.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean T. Collins
title: ‘Shogun’ Episode 9 Recap: an Army of One
description: Lady Mariko is bound to her orders, which force the hand of Lord Ishido and Lady Ochiba.
content: It’s a deception by which even the ingenious Lord Toranaga would be impressed. Step one: Spend several episodes of your prestige-drama period piece touting “Crimson Sky,” a battle plan for an all-out assault on a medieval castle the brutality of which frightens even Toranaga himself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ginia Bellafante
title: In the Hamptons, a Grim Paradox Revealed
description: On Long Island’s East End, where many residents retreat to lavish second homes, some day laborers who can’t afford a bed are living in outdoor encampments.
content: In early January, I got a call from someone I know who spends time in Sagaponack on the East End of Long Island. She told me about men, most of them undocumented immigrants from Guatemala and Mexico, who live in encampments in the woods, in the shadows of all the money and the opulent comforts of the Hamptons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes and Chang W. Lee
title: In Australia, ‘Cats Are Just Catastrophic’
description: Feral cats take a heavy toll on the world’s wildlife, especially Down Under. The solution? Smarter traps, sharpshooters, survival camp for prey species, and the “Felixer.”
content: Katherine Moseby wanted to be clear: She does not hate cats. “They’re a wily beast,” she said, as her truck rumbled down a desert road. “But I respect them. They’re pretty incredible animals. Amazing hunters. Very smart.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter
title: Book Bans Continue to Surge in Public Schools
description: More books were removed during the first half of this academic year than in the entire previous one.
content: Book bans in public schools continued to surge in the first half of this school year, according to a report released on Tuesday by PEN America, a free speech organization.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Gains and Losses: Dr. Bob and the Realities of Aging
description: Responses to a front-page story about an aging doctor. Also: Donald Trump’s snooze in court; women vs. Trump; free speech’s limits; the gun show
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracy Mumford, Jonah E. Bromwich, Ian Stewart, Jessica Metzger and James Shield
title: Supreme Court to Hear Jan. 6 Case, and Trump’s Criminal Trial Gets Underway
description: Plus, NASA’s “Hail Mary.”
content: On Today’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Will the French Olympic Team Be Best Dressed at the Opening Ceremony?
description: Carine Roitfeld teamed up with Berluti to sprinkle some fashion fairy dust on the designs. Here’s the verdict.
content: In the sprawling fashion show that will be the 2024 Summer Olympics — the various ceremonial fits, the performance uniforms, the podium kit, the merch — there is perhaps no more freighted look than what the French delegation will wear to the opening ceremony.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne
title: What Sign, Symbol or Emoji Best Represents Your Generation?
description: And what does it say about you and your peers — your experiences, your interests, your hopes and your worries?
content: When you see peace signs, like those pinned to the graduation caps in the image above, what comes to mind? Does the symbol mean anything to you? Why do you think the students in the photograph might have been wearing it?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘The One-Liners Kept Coming’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: “I’ll gladly pay you Tuesday for a Coke today.” The last words my father said to me. I had just brought him a Coke, fulfilling a raspy request from his deathbed. At first, I thought his offer was gibberish spurting from his rapidly progressing neurodegenerative disease. When I told my mom, she immediately understood — he was riffing on Wimpy’s catchphrase from the “Popeye” cartoon. In those final days, the one-liners kept coming: Could I get him anything? A winning lottery ticket. Anyone he wanted to see? Bob Dylan. He didn’t make it to Tuesday, but his debt had been repaid. — Susannah Clark Matt
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: Americans Are More Vulnerable to Foreign Propaganda, Senator Warns
description: Senator Mark Warner, the chairman of the Intelligence Committee, said the United States was more susceptible to Russian influence operations than it was during the 2020 elections.
content: The threat against U.S. elections by Russia and other foreign powers is far greater today than it was in 2020, the chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: A Pathbreaking Singer Arrives at the Met, With Pearls and Tattoos
description: Dav­óne Tines, who stars in the oratorio “El Niño,” is challenging traditions in classical music and using art to confront social problems.
content: The bass-baritone Dav­óne Tines, wearing Dr. Martens boots, a sleeveless black shirt and six vintage pearl rings, stood on a rehearsal stage at the Metropolitan Opera in Manhattan the other day and began to sing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Secret Rift Over Data Center Fueled Push to Expand Reach of Surveillance Program
description: Privacy advocates are raising alarms about a mysterious provision the House added to a surveillance bill last week. The Senate is likely to vote on the bill later this week.
content: A hidden dispute over whether a data center for cloud computing must cooperate with a warrantless surveillance program prompted the House last week to add a mysterious provision to a bill extending the program, according to people familiar with the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Jimison
title: Cotton Urges Citizens to Forcibly Confront Pro-Palestinian Protesters
description: The Republican senator from Arkansas said citizens should “take matters into your own hands” against demonstrators who have stepped up their civil disobedience to protest Israel’s offensive in Gaza.
content: Senator Tom Cotton, Republican of Arkansas, on Monday urged people whose routes were blocked by pro-Palestinian protesters to “take matters into your own hands” and confront the offenders, endorsing the use of physical force against peaceful demonstrators.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Walker
title: Buttigieg Teams Up With State Attorneys General to Investigate Airline Complaints
description: Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg announced a new partnership with more than a dozen state attorneys general that aims to improve protections for air travelers.
content: Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg on Tuesday announced a new partnership with more than a dozen state attorneys general to investigate consumer complaints against airlines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich, Maggie Haberman and Ben Protess
title: As Trump Runs in 2024, His 2016 Tactics Are on Trial
description: Prosecutors in Donald J. Trump’s criminal trial secured permission from the judge to admit evidence connected to his overall political strategy in 2016, bolstering their case.
content: Donald J. Trump first ran for president as a Republican nearly a decade ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Capitol Attack Prosecutions Have Ensnared Over 1,380 People
description: Prosecutors have suggested that a total of 2,000 or 2,500 people could ultimately face indictment for their roles in the attack.
content: The investigation of the Jan. 6, 2021, Capitol attack is already the largest criminal inquiry in Justice Department history, federal prosecutors have said. And even after more than three years, it has shown little sign of slowing down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: ‘Pasta Nada’ and More Ultrafast, Flexible Dinners
description: Few ingredients and very versatile: creamy garlic pasta with greens, soy-glazed chicken breasts, kimchi fried rice.
content: I’ve recently returned from spring break, where I scrounged a few quiet minutes to lie down poolside and devour “The Upstairs Delicatessen,” by Dwight Garner, a book critic here at The New York Times and a known eater of exceptional taste. The subtitle of this memoir: “On Eating, Reading, Reading About Eating, and Eating While Reading.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrina Miller
title: Comet Pons-Brooks Is Having Its Last Hurrah
description: Soon, this devil-horned comet won’t be visible for another seven decades.
content: Time is running out for you to spot Pons-Brooks, the devil-horned comet that swoops into view once every 71 years. Last visible to people on Earth in the 1950s, the comet is prone to outbursts, or unexpected flares in brightness.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: April 16, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, April 16, 2024.
content: An article on Friday about the possible impact that psychedelics could have on survivors of the Oct. 7 terror attacks in Israel misspelled the surname of psychology professor at the University of Haifa. He is Roee Admon, not Edmon. The article also misspelled the given name of a cognitive science professor at the school. He is Roy Salomon, not Roi.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Paton
title: The British (Fashion Brands) Are Coming!
description: Three beloved London brands are making their way across the Atlantic to stake a bricks and mortar presence in the United States.
content: Britain’s fashion brands have long looked to the United States for a chance to supersize sales — with varying degrees of success. For every Boden, there is a Topshop, Ted Baker or Hunter Boots that failed to successfully crack the market. After all, the United States is much larger, more diverse and already has plenty of fashion labels to choose from. Garments with an appealing English eccentricity or appeal in their home market may feel out of touch in major American shopping hubs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Salt
description: Are you consuming too much?
content: Do you pay attention to the amount of salt in everyday foods? Do you think you are consuming too much?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura May Todd
title: Take a Tour of T’s Salone del Mobile Party With Ramdane Touhami
description: The designer shows off the mirrored installation and T-shaped desserts he dreamed up for the annual celebration.
content: For T Magazine’s annual Salone del Mobile party, which this year also celebrated the magazine’s 20th anniversary, the designer and entrepreneur Ramdane Touhami oversaw a festive installation in the garden of Milan’s Villa Necchi Campiglio, a Rationalist-style house dating to 1935. In addition to running his creative agency, Art Recherche Industrie, the Paris-based Touhami founded the Société Helvétique d’Impression Typographique, a printing press and typography studio. He’s long been interested in the visual appeal of the alphabet, so when he took over the villa’s garden, he planned a theme that revolved around a single letter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Man Sentenced to 35 Years in Prison for Kidnapping F.B.I. Worker
description: Juan Alvarez-Sorto and two other people were on a drug trafficking trip in 2022 when they carjacked an S.U.V. belonging to a crime victim specialist, federal prosecutors said.
content: Curt Lauinger, an F.B.I. employee, had just left a crime scene early one morning in May 2022, and was driving toward Rapid City, S.D., when he stopped on the side of the road because he thought he was being pulled over by the police, according to court documents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: For Israel’s Allies, Iranian Missile Strike Scrambles Debate Over Gaza
description: Israel’s restless allies have voiced anger over the death toll in Gaza, but when their archnemesis launched a missile barrage, they set it aside. At least for the moment.
content: Two weeks ago, Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain was facing a chorus of calls to cut off arms shipments to Israel because of its devastating war in Gaza. On Monday, Mr. Sunak saluted the British warplanes that had shot down several Iranian drones as part of a successful campaign to thwart Iran’s attack on Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: Restaurant Review: Hamburger America Is Deliriously Messy
description: Oklahoma-style onion burgers are the rage this year. At George Motz’s new SoHo restaurant, they reach their drippy peak.
content: Every once in a while, restaurateurs in New York become infatuated with the cuisine of some other place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Carl Erskine, a Star Pitcher of the Dodgers’ Glory Years, Is Dead at 97
description: The record-setting pitcher known as Oisk in Brooklyn was the last surviving member of “The Boys of Summer.”
content: Carl Erskine, who set a World Series strikeout record, threw two no-hitters and became one of the Brooklyn Dodgers’ top pitchers in their glory years of the 1950s, died on Tuesday in Anderson, Ind., his hometown. He was 97.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aimee Ortiz
title: A Year’s Worth of Rain Fell in Dubai on a Single Day
description: The United Arab Emirates had its largest rainfall in 75 years as a year’s worth of rain fell in Dubai alone, temporarily halting flights. More rain is expected into Wednesday.
content: Follow our coverage of the flooding in Oman and Dubai.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Anderson
title: The Rom-Com That’s Responsible for My Marriage
description: The 1992 movie “Singles” changed my life.
content: Dear 1994 Sam Anderson: Hello. It’s me, 2024 Sam Anderson – you from the future, exactly 30 years from now. (I’m explaining because you are bad at math.) I am typing this on technology that doesn’t exist yet. I’m older than your parents currently are. I have a big beard, and my lower back hurts, and I spend most of my time playing word games or reading apocalyptic news alerts on the supercomputer I keep in my pocket. The 21st century, to be honest, sucks. To put it in terms you’ll understand: We’re trying to swing on the flippity flop, but we’re living in a harsh realm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Fairness, a Trump Obsession, Is Central to Jury Selection in His Trial
description: The laborious process of selecting the people who will decide Donald J. Trump’s fate hinges on whether they can judge him impartially.
content: Over much of his life, Donald J. Trump has measured the world in terms of whether it is treating him or people he likes “unfairly.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Long Dismissed, the Beatles’ ‘Let It Be’ Film Returns After 54 Years
description: Michael Lindsay-Hogg’s unloved — or misinterpreted? — 1970 documentary, the source for Peter Jackson’s “Get Back,” will stream on Disney+.
content: In 2021, the director Peter Jackson’s sprawling and vibrant Beatles docuseries, “The Beatles: Get Back,” streamed on Disney+ to nearly universal acclaim. The three-part epic, which ran nearly eight hours, captured the drama and frenzy as John Lennon, Paul McCartney, George Harrison and Ringo Starr recorded, over the pressure-filled month of January 1969, what would become the last album that the Beatles released, “Let It Be.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin
title: NPR Suspends Editor Whose Essay Criticized the Broadcaster
description: Uri Berliner, a senior business editor at NPR, said the public radio network’s liberal bias had tainted its coverage of important stories.
content: NPR has suspended Uri Berliner, the senior business editor who broke ranks and published an essay arguing that the nonprofit radio network had allowed liberal bias to affect its coverage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Tuesday Briefing
description: A chance for U.S. aid to Ukraine and Israel.
content: Speaker Mike Johnson said that he planned to advance a long-stalled national security spending package this week to aid Israel, Ukraine and other U.S. allies, coupled with a bill to mollify conservatives opposed to backing Kyiv.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley
title: The Met, Amid an Audit of its Holdings, Returns an Ancient Statue to Iraq
description: The museum said its enhanced effort to study the provenance of items in its collection had turned up evidence that the statue of a Sumerian man was the property of Iraq.
content: The Metropolitan Museum of Art said on Tuesday it has returned a Sumerian sculpture dating from the third millennium B.C. to Iraq and described the repatriation as a product of the museum’s more intensive efforts to review the provenance of items in its collection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter
title: Wednesday Briefing: China’s Economy Grew Faster Than Expected
description: Plus, Australia’s feral cat problem.
content: China’s National Bureau of Statistics said yesterday that the economy grew 1.6 percent in the first quarter over the previous three months, despite a severe real estate crisis and sluggish spending at home. When projected out for the entire year, the first-quarter data indicates that the economy was growing at an annual rate of about 6.6 percent. China had set a growth target of about 5 percent for the year, a goal that many economists viewed as ambitious.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Kisa Brings South Korean Roadside Fare to the Lower East Side
description: Rosemary’s offers pizza and a family-style meal in Midtown, the owners of Oxalis open Laurel Bakery in the Columbia Street waterfront district, Brooklyn, and more restaurant news.
content: In South Korea, roadside diners that cater to taxi drivers are called kisa sikdang, or “driver’s restaurants,” and serve baekban (homestyle) fare like bibimbap, spicy pork or local, fresh seafood with rice and banchan. Kisa serves most of these as well as bulgogi and spicy squid. The owners, David JoonWoo Yun, Steve JaeWoo Choi and Yong Min Kim, all South Korean natives, are behind C as in Charlie in NoHo. (Taxi drivers prefer rice dishes to soups, they say, because bathroom breaks are rare.) The room’s vintage touches include Korean calendars, wall-mounted fans and a machine that dispenses free coffee. (Opens Saturday)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tina Antolini, Wendy Dorr, Sophia Lanman and Sarah Lyall
title: In ‘Knife,’ Salman Rushdie Recounts His Brush With Death
description: Our reporter on the author’s new memoir.
content: In his new memoir “Knife,” Salman Rushdie recounts the harrowing stabbing that nearly killed him in August 2022, and his physical and emotional recovery in the time since.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: House Delivers Impeachment Articles Against Mayorkas, Calling for a Trial
description: Republicans are demanding a full trial of the homeland security secretary, but Democrats have made it clear they will try to dismiss the charges quickly and with little fanfare.
content: After two months of delay, House Republicans on Tuesday delivered articles of impeachment against Alejandro N. Mayorkas, the homeland security secretary, to the Senate, as they demanded a full trial of the first sitting cabinet secretary to be impeached by Congress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman and Jim Tankersley
title: Powell Suggests Interest Rates Could Stay High for a Longer Period
description: The Fed chair, along with the central bank’s No. 2 policymaker, stressed uncertainties over job growth and the persistence of elevated inflation.
content: The Federal Reserve is likely to wait longer than initially expected to cut interest rates, given stubborn inflation readings in recent months, the central bank’s top two officials said Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Christobek
title: The Challenge of Keeping Prospective Trump Jurors Anonymous
description: In responding to questions during jury selection, several revealed employment and other information that could identify them.
content: Last month, the judge in Donald J. Trump’s criminal trial in Manhattan ordered that prospective jurors’ names would be shielded from the public, underscoring the need for privacy for those who may decide the former president’s fate — and tempt the anger of his followers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: A $1.7 Million Toilet and Liberalism’s Failure to Build
description: Jerusalem Demsas discusses the red tape that makes it difficult for blue states to achieve ambitious infrastructure and policy goals.
content: There is so much we need to build right now. The housing crunch has spread across the country; by one estimate, we’re a few million units short. And we also need a huge build-out of renewable energy infrastructure — at a scale some experts compare to the construction of the Interstate highway system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Protess, Jonah E. Bromwich, Maggie Haberman and Wesley Parnell
title: Prosecutors and Defense Lawyers Begin to Seat Jurors for Trump Trial
description: The prospective jurors questioned on Tuesday mirrored their city: diverse, opinionated and with strong views about the former president.
content: The daunting work of selecting a jury for the first criminal trial of a former American president rapidly gained momentum on Tuesday as seven New Yorkers were picked to sit in judgment of Donald J. Trump, accelerating a crucial phase of the case that many had expected to be a slog.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Jerusalem Demsas
description: The April 16, 2024, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Jerusalem Demsas. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Did Three African Runners Let a Chinese Runner Win a Race in Beijing?
description: Organizers are investigating the results of the Beijing Half Marathon, after three runners from Kenya and Ethiopia appeared to wave a Chinese competitor past them before the finish.
content: After a grueling hour, there was little to separate the four runners as the finish line approached. But then, one extended his hand toward another and gestured, as if waving him forward. Seconds later, another runner did the same.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Miller
title: Donald Trump Is His Own Chaos Whisperer
description: At rallies, he does alt-universe loops in which he suggests that if the election hadn’t been taken from him, nothing bad would have befallen the world.
content: On Saturday night, while Iran fired drones and missiles into Israel, Donald Trump talked a lot about chaos.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: How to Be Pro-Palestinian, Pro-Israeli and Pro-Iranian
description: Support leadership change in Iran, Israel and the Palestinian Authority. Without that, there’s zero chance for resolution.
content: Iran’s missile and drone attack on Israel over the weekend was a game-changing escalation that requires some game-changing rethinking on the part of Israel and its most important ally, the United States. I call it “the three-state solution.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sandra E. Garcia
title: A ‘Nature School’ Meets in Brooklyn
description: A series of workshops hosted by the artist collective Field Meridians will try to get New Yorkers to open their eyes to the nature all around them.
content: Nature is all around us, even in New York City. Though it can be difficult to appreciate the magnolia and ginkgo trees when running to catch the subway, we are in fact surrounded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Israeli Artist Shuts Biennale Show, Urging Cease-Fire and Hostage Release
description: Ruth Patir, Israel’s representative at the Venice Biennale, says she won’t open her show in the national pavilion until “a cease-fire and hostage release agreement is reached.”
content: Since February thousands of pro-Palestinian activists have tried in vain to get the Venice Biennale, one of the world’s most prestigious international art exhibitions, to ban Israel over its conduct of the war in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anemona Hartocollis
title: The House Republican Going After Universities on Antisemitism
description: Representative Virginia Foxx is a blunt partisan. But her life in rural North Carolina informs her attacks against these schools, starting with whether Harvard is truly “elite.”
content: Virginia Foxx, the Republican congresswoman from North Carolina, has spent the last few months giving elite schools a hard time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley
title: Inside the Manhattan Courtroom at the Center of American Politics
description: Protesters railed outside, media and security swarmed the area, and inside the courtroom, Donald J. Trump appeared to nod off.
content: It was about 2:30 on Monday afternoon when the first 96 potential jurors filed into a drab courtroom in Lower Manhattan to encounter the world’s most famous defendant: Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: Let’s Keep This Vintage Fashion Boutique Just Between Us
description: A laid-back shop in Los Angeles is a semi-secret spot for celebrities and costume designers.
content: Vintage-clothing aficionados are either pawing through piles of polyester looking for that one treasure, arms itching and aching … or paying an obscene amount for something that the passage of time has made fragile, even if it doesn’t have sweat stains (and it might!).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronen Bergman, Isabel Kershner, Julian E. Barnes and Russell Goldman
title: Israel Weighs Response to Iran Attack, With Each Choice a Risk
description: In debating how to respond to last weekend’s Iranian airstrike, Israel’s war cabinet is choosing between options that could deter future attacks or de-escalate hostilities, but all carry drawbacks.
content: Israeli leaders on Tuesday were debating how best to respond to Iran’s unprecedented weekend airstrike, officials said, weighing a set of options calibrated to achieve different strategic outcomes: deterring a similar attack in the future, placating their American allies and avoiding all-out war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Supreme Court’s Review of Jan. 6 Charge Has Already Freed Some Rioters
description: Federal judges have agreed to release about 10 defendants who were serving prison terms because of their convictions under an obstruction law.
content: Follow live coverage of the Jan. 6 obstruction case at the Supreme Court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alisha Haridasani Gupta
title: For Postpartum and Pregnancy Care, One Brand Turns to a Porn Star
description: The mother and baby care brand Frida is working with Asa Akira, a well-known porn actress, to create educational videos about its products.
content: The video shows Asa Akira lying on the bed, naked from the hips down, with her legs splayed open. Her hair is thrown into a messy bun. Then she reaches for some lubricant and a long, curved device.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas
title: Biden Bashes Trump as a Pawn of Billionaires as He Lays Out His Tax Plan
description: Speaking in Scranton, Pa., his hometown, the president used a speech about economic fairness as a new avenue of attack against his Republican rival, who was in a courtroom two hours away.
content: President Biden delivered a flurry of attacks on former President Donald J. Trump during a Tuesday speech in Pennsylvania about taxes and economic policy, painting his Republican rival as a puppet of plutocrats who had ignored the working class.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Davis O'Brien
title: Trump, Trailing Biden in Cash, Relies on Big Donors to Try to Catch Up
description: Major Republican donors have begun to open their checkbooks for Donald Trump now that he is the presumptive nominee, as he struggles to keep pace with President Biden.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump leaned heavily on major Republican donors in March as his campaign and the Republican Party sought to close the financial gap separating him from President Biden, new federal filings showed on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: After 5,631 Yankees Games, John Sterling Calls His Own Walk-Off
description: The WFAN announcer was known for his catchphrase, “It is high! It is far! It is gone!” His last game was on Monday.
content: John Sterling and Suzyn Waldman had that special sort of radio relationship where they would often finish each other’s sentences, or more precisely, each other’s lyrics. They might have been announcing Yankees games, but that would not prevent them from dipping into musical theater, a passion for both of them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: Will a Housing Deal Make New York More Affordable?
description: New York leaders agreed to a framework designed to help the state build more housing and keep prices down. Here is how it could work.
content: New York State officials have set the stage to take action on the state’s housing crisis. On Monday, the governor announced a framework for a package of housing laws that would make it easier to build homes and curb the skyrocketing cost of living.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Craig Marks
title: Taylor Swift and Beyoncé Avoided a Collision on the Charts. (Again.)
description: Pop’s two reigning queens are often cast as rivals, but they have continually supported each other — and spaced out their album releases.
content: In February, Taylor Swift took the stage at the Grammy Awards to accept the prize for best pop vocal album. After dutifully thanking the Recording Academy and her fans, she got down to business: “My brand-new album comes out April 19,” she said, in a surprise announcement revealing “The Tortured Poets Department.” It was a heads up for her loyal followers, as well as anyone else in the business with a spring release on the radar: If you want your new album to debut at No. 1, don’t release it on April 19. Or April 26. Or May 3, for that matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Wu
title: The Popularity of Marathons
description: Participation is up — as are finish times.
content: On a chilly day in April 1924 — the first year that the Boston Marathon was 26.2 miles, rather than the original 24.8 miles — around 140 men lined up in Hopkinton, Mass., to race. Yesterday, a century later in that same town, about 30,000 runners crossed the starting line.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons and William K. Rashbaum
title: Mayor Adams Pushes to Hire Ex-Giuliani Deputy as New York’s Top Lawyer
description: Mayor Eric Adams, who is facing a cluster of legal challenges, is moving to hire Randy Mastro, known for his aggressive tactics.
content: With Mayor Eric Adams and top aides facing a tangle of investigations and lawsuits, he is quietly maneuvering to replace New York City’s top lawyer with a veteran litigator known for his aggressive tactics, two people who are familiar with the matter said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Trump’s Jan. 6 Case Could Go On Even if Court Limits Use of Obstruction Law
description: The federal indictment of Donald Trump for plotting to overturn the 2020 election relies in part on the law that the Supreme Court weighed on Tuesday, but was built to survive without it.
content: Even though Donald J. Trump was never mentioned during the Supreme Court’s hearing on Tuesday about a federal obstruction statute used against hundreds of his supporters who stormed the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, the former president loomed large over the proceeding.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Why Biden Has a Narrower Path to the Presidency Than Trump, in 11 Maps

title: Flash Floods Swamp Dubai
description: The desert city was overwhelmed by a torrential downpour that dumped a year’s worth of rain in less than a day.

author: By The New York Times
title: Biden Digs at Trump During His Pennsylvania Hometown Visit
description: In a speech about his tax plan, President Biden compared Scranton, Pa., to Trump’s Mar-a-Lago to highlight the different economic and social values between America’s middle class and its wealthy.
content: In a speech about his tax plan, President Biden compared Scranton, Pa., to Trump’s Mar-a-Lago to highlight the different economic and social values between America’s middle class and its wealthy.
